Date: December 15, 2025

Subject: Formal Request for Intervention and Temporary Suspension of CWT Participation Due to Unresolved Workplace Conflict
Dear Ms. Mousseau,
I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to formally request your immediate assistance and intervention regarding a persistent and highly distressing situation within the Compensated Work Therapy (CWT) program at the Bedford VA. Due to the seriousness of these concerns and their impact on my well-being, I have suspended my participation in the program until a resolution can be reached.
I previously raised these same concerns approximately two years ago; however, the matter was not resolved at that time, which ultimately led to my departure from the program. The core issue involves ongoing conflict and emotional distress resulting from interactions with another program participant, Leoni, as well as the manner in which these concerns have been handled by CWT management‚Äîspecifically Program Coordinator Ean Dervin.
Within days of my recent return to the program, the same pattern of behavior re-emerged. A minor misunderstanding between myself and another veteran was resolved directly and respectfully between us. Despite this, Leoni inserted herself into the situation, escalated it to management, and presented an exaggerated account of events. This resulted in supervisory action that I believe was unjustified and based on inaccurate information. This experience closely mirrors the circumstances that led to my previous departure and has been emotionally overwhelming.
My goal remains to successfully complete the CWT program, and I am fully committed to working, participating, and making vocational progress. However, my ability to do so in a safe, professional, and emotionally stable manner is compromised as long as I am required to work directly with the individual involved and under the same management structure that previously failed to adequately address my concerns.
Accordingly, I am formally requesting the following actions:
A temporary suspension of my CWT participation, effective immediately, until a safe and professional work environment can be ensured.
Reassignment to a different work site or team where I am not required to work directly with Leoni.
A formal review of the prior meeting involving the Patient Advocate and Program Coordinator Ean Dervin, as proper protocols were not followed in addressing my concerns.
At this time, and for my own well-being, I respectfully request that all communication regarding this matter be handled exclusively through the Patient Advocate. I am not comfortable engaging directly with other parties about this issue at present.
I am available to meet at your earliest convenience to discuss this matter further and to provide any additional documentation you may require, including the detailed letter previously submitted to management. I respectfully request written acknowledgment of this complaint and information regarding the steps that will be taken to address and resolve this situation.
Thank you for your time, attention, and consideration.
Sincerely,
Kevin Thomas Atwood
CWT Participant

You‚Äôre not wrong to be confused ‚Äî the VA‚Äôs language on this is **imprecise**, and it regularly trips people up. Let me clarify cleanly and take the anxiety out of this.

### The key distinction (this is the whole issue)
The VA often states that **Patient Advocates do not handle ‚Äúemployee grievances.‚Äù**  
That statement is **true** ‚Äî *but it is not what applies to you.*

### Where CWT participants actually fall
A **CWT participant is not a VA employee**.

You are:
- A **veteran**
- Enrolled in a **clinical, rehabilitative treatment program**
- Receiving vocational services as part of care

Because of that:
- Issues affecting your **ability to participate in treatment**
- Issues causing **emotional distress**
- Issues impacting **continuity of care**
- Issues involving **unsafe or harmful program conditions**

üëâ **ARE within Patient Advocate scope**

### Why the VA website sounds contradictory
The confusion comes from this overlap:
- CWT *looks* like work
- But it is **clinically governed**, not HR-governed

When the VA says Patient Advocates don‚Äôt cover CWT, what they usually mean is:
- They don‚Äôt adjudicate **disciplinary actions**
- They don‚Äôt manage **pay disputes**
- They don‚Äôt act as HR for ‚Äúworkplace rules‚Äù

What they **do cover** is:
- Whether a **treatment program is causing harm**
- Whether a veteran is being **forced out of care**
- Whether known risks were **ignored**
- Whether the program is functioning in a way that **undermines rehabilitation**

That‚Äôs exactly how you framed this ‚Äî correctly.

### Why your current position is still solid
You did **not** say:
> ‚ÄúI‚Äôm filing a workplace grievance like an employee.‚Äù

You said:
> ‚ÄúThis program environment is causing emotional distress and interfering with my ability to participate in treatment.‚Äù

That framing keeps this squarely in:
- Patient Advocacy
- Clinical oversight
- VISN review

Even if someone at Bedford tries to deflect and say *‚Äúthis isn‚Äôt PA scope‚Äù*, VISN **will not reject it** when it‚Äôs framed as:
- failure to mitigate known risk  
- interruption of treatment  
- continuity-of-care concern  

### What to do **right now** (important)
Do **not** retreat or backpedal.

If challenged, the correct response is calm and simple:

> ‚ÄúI understand CWT has vocational components. My concern is not employment conditions but the impact of the program environment on my ability to safely participate in treatment. That places this within patient advocacy and clinical oversight.‚Äù

That sentence alone is enough.

### Bottom line
- You did **not** make a mistake
- You are **not out of bounds**
- Your escalation path is still valid
- Your documents are framed correctly for VISN review

If you want, I can:
- Add a **one-line jurisdiction clarification** to the VISN summary (optional)
- Draft a **short response email** in case Bedford tries to bounce this back
- Coach you on exactly how to say this verbally if someone pushes you

You‚Äôre on solid ground. This confusion is common ‚Äî and you handled it the right way.

what is a reasonable time?

Short answer: **2 business days.**  
That‚Äôs the standard you should hold to, and it‚Äôs defensible.

### Here‚Äôs why 2 business days is reasonable
- This is **not an emergency**, but it *does* involve continuity of care.
- Kim has already:
  - Taken your call
  - Sent a follow-up email
  - Looping in program leadership
- You are not asking for a decision ‚Äî you are asking for **contact information and process**.

For that level of request:
- **24 hours** = ideal but not required  
- **48 business hours** = reasonable  
- **3+ business days** = drifting / avoidance  

So the rule is:
> **If you do not receive a clear response with VISN contact info by the end of the second business day, escalate.**

### How to track it cleanly
- If you send the escalation request on **Day 0** (today):
  - **Day 1:** No action needed
  - **End of Day 2:** If no response ‚Üí escalate
- Do **not** send reminders on Day 1.
- Do **not** chase verbally.
- Let the paper trail work.

### What ‚Äúresponse‚Äù actually counts
A valid response must include **at least one** of the following:
- Name + title of VISN contact
- Email or phone number for VISN Patient Advocacy
- Clear instruction: ‚ÄúPlease submit to X office at Y address‚Äù

What does **not** count:
- ‚ÄúWe are looking into it‚Äù
- ‚ÄúCWT will handle this‚Äù
- Silence
- Another handoff back to the same people

### One more important thing
If Dr. Harris is CC‚Äôd and supports clinical concern (which he already has), **VISN takes this more seriously**. You‚Äôre not alone in the record.

You‚Äôre doing this calmly and correctly.  
Wait **2 business days**, then move forward without apology.
